posts.title: The Night Watch
posts.subtitle: Emergency child welfare calls skyrocket on weekend nights.
posts.teaser: Los Angeles County social workers who respond to emergency calls at night find that weekends bring the most danger for children.
posts.body:
For social workers who knock unbidden on doors where child welfare complaints have been filed, Friday and Saturday nights are always the busiest.

On any given night, about two dozen emergency response social workers work late into the evening, responding to child abuse calls from all over Los Angeles County.

"A typical Friday night could be anywhere from 40 to 55 child abuse investigations for my staff," Javier Avila, a supervisor at the Los Angeles Department of Child and Family Services.

We followed two social workers on their late-night rounds, knocking on doors, waking up families in the middle of the night and trying to determine if children were safe.

Friday nights also seem to bring the worst cases.  "It can include child accidents, child fatalities, near drownings, or near fatalities," Avila says. "So we pretty much get the very severe types of cases on Friday and Saturday nights."

If the social worker determines that the child is in immediate danger, they will remove her from the house immediately. She might end up in a police station or in a conference room at the massive cubicle farm that is DCFS headquarters in Downtown Los Angeles.

category.title: Images
category.description: The heartbeat of AudioVision. The best from our team of photojournalists — and discover images from the photographers who inspire them.

assets.title: 02 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: Social worker Gesenia Macias leaves an apartment with two police officers after unsuccessfully trying to find the parents in a reported neglect case.

assets.title: 01 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: Social worker Alfred McCloud knocks on the front door of a home in south L.A. to check on a toddler. McCloud works the night shift with the Department of Child and Family Services' Emergency Response Team.

assets.title: 03 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: McCloud tries to figure out if there's anyone home at an apartment in the south Bay during a call for a report of abuse. The mother wasn't home and McCloud traveled on to the father's house.

assets.title: 04 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: The residence in south L.A. is home to two young mothers with four toddlers. One of the mothers, Susana, recently fled an abusive relationship.

assets.title: 05 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: McCloud walks by baskets with forms used in processing DCFS investigations. Every night, about two dozen emergency response workers are on hand to handle reports of abuse and neglect.

assets.title: 06 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: A conference room serves as a holding area for children taken into protective custody by DCFS. This room can fill up at night.

assets.title: 07 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: McCloud reads up on a case before heading out into the field at the DCFS headquarters south of downtown Los Angeles. The offices are a warren of cubicles that takes up six floors above the L.A. Mart shopping center.

assets.title: 08 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: Temporary cots fill a conference room at the DCFS headquarters south of downtown Los Angeles. Children taken into protective custody sometimes spend the night in the agency's fifth floor offices.

assets.title: 09 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: Social worker Ladore Winzer staffs the hotline through the night at the DCFS headquarters south of downtown Los Angeles. Friday night is one of the busiest for the department.

assets.title: 10 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: McCloud speaks with Susana in private in her bedroom, as he tries to ascertain her current state and the health of her child.

assets.title: 11 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: An unused piece of luggage is left behind in a room used for children who have been taken into protective custody.

assets.title: 12 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: McCloud speaks with his supervisor. He usually consults with the DCFS office before leaving a scene.

assets.title: 13 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: Alfred McCloud fills out paperwork at the end of the home visit. He has decided that the child is safe and can stay with Susana.

assets.title: 14 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: Social worker Gesenia Macias is accompanied by a police officer as she checks to see if a family is home shortly before midnight.

assets.title: 15 - DCFS Night Shift
assets.caption: McCloud looks into the windows of a second-floor apartment in the south Bay to see if there are any lights on. Depending on the circumstances, case workers visit one to three homes a night.

posts.title: Public Square • Thankful For
posts.subtitle: This month we want to see what you're thankful for.
posts.teaser: Every month we team up with NPR to bring you Public Square -- a community Instagram project. For November, we want to see what you're thankful for.
posts.body:
It's time again for our Public Square community project with NPR.

November's Theme: #PSThankfulFor 

Since Thanksgiving is almost upon us, we want to see the people, places and things that you're thankful for.

It could be someone close to you, the view from your window or the smile from a stranger. Get creative, capture your subject in a photo or video and tag it #PSThankfulFor.

In the caption please tell us who/what you are thankful for and why.

Public radio is all about storytelling, so please don't skimp on the caption! While we love pretty pictures, we are suckers for a good story.

Project Rules

Please tag only one photo posted to Instagram from November 15th to 30th with #PSThankfulFor.

Any image posted with the tag in the next 15 days is eligible to featured here on Instagram, KPCC's AudioVision and NPR's The Picture Show.

You can follow KPCC and NPR on Instagram for project updates.

Have fun telling your story! We can't wait to see it.

category.title: Images
category.description: The heartbeat of AudioVision. The best from our team of photojournalists — and discover images from the photographers who inspire them.

assets.title: #PSThankfulFor Public Square
assets.caption: For our Public Square Instagram project in November we want to see your photos of the people, places and things that you're thankful for. Tag your images #PSThankfulFor.

posts.title: Exploring industrial Los Angeles
posts.subtitle: Stella Kalinina looks at the machines that make L.A.
posts.teaser: Los Angeles is a land of machines, from the cars that crowd our freeways to the ships that come in to our ports. Visual artist Stella Kalinina films them.
posts.body:
Los Angeles is a land of machines, from the cars that crowd our freeways to the cranes that unload ships in our parts.

Visual artist Stella Kalinina is in the middle of a project that explores parts of the machinery of America's second largest city.

Her first video takes you to the Port of Los Angeles where huge machines offload the goods that fuel American commerce.

Kalinina, a student at Art Center College in Pasadena, blends sound and visuals in an interesting way that gives the machinations of the port a new life.

Her second video explores the pumpjacks that dot the hills of Long Beach and along La Cienega Boulevard.

The images are interspersed with audio of residents talking about their neighbors that suck oil from the earth like birds drinking from a straw.

(Via LA, I'm Yours)

category.title: Video
category.description: Southern California, as seen through our own eyes — and a tour of the best in web video today.

posts.title: Inside the world of illustrator Michael Hsiung
posts.subtitle: Learn what makes this LA-based artist tick.
posts.teaser: LA-based artist Michael Hsiung was never comfortable in a suit in tie. Learn how he left the corporate world behind and pursued his passion as an illustrator.
posts.body:
Michael Hsiung is a product of Southern California; he was born in Chinatown, raised in the Valley and consumed by skateboard and surfing culture.

After stints in the corporate world, Hsiung realized he was much happier as an illustrator and decided to take off from his nine to five job.

Learn more about Hsiung's philosophy and career in this video by Ambig and Hidden Notice.

category.title: Video
category.description: Southern California, as seen through our own eyes — and a tour of the best in web video today.

assets.title: Michael Hammer Hsiung
assets.caption: Learn about the career and philosophy of LA-based illustrator Michael Hammer Hsiung.
